title: UNESCO Recommendation on OER

presenter: Gašper Hrastelj, Slovenska nacionalna komisija za UNESCO

segmentation: Since 2014, I think when when the Joseph Steffan Research Institute, in cooperation with the University in Nova Goritsy came to US and started the initiative in order to establish the UNESCO Chair in this field.
Um, since then we are working very closely together and it was only then when the time came up that I learned about this.
Topics about open education about all technologies and about all programs and applications and everything.
What is possible in this field, and it was a demonstration first to me and to us what in Slovenia was already achieved until then.
But when we came together at international events at global Inter Organization?
Global events in the field of open education, then colleagues from UNESCO and also from other partner institutions and and stakeholders, governments and universities and so on.
It was proven that to them that Slovenia had also on global level on global scale, something to demonstrate and to show.
And that was why we were approached by UNESCO itself and by other partners.
And they asked us if we would be in Slovenia prepared to host the Second World Congress in open educational resources.
Second, because it would have been then after five years after the first one which took place in two 12 in Paris itself at UNESCO headquarters.
Um?

They already also supported the First World Congress.
Here they were responsible too.
To support especially the regional consultations which took place before the Congress.

Small tiny country, but in the Meanwhile, at least in this field we are in the center of the world.
So that's why we decided to call it the world Slovenia map now and.
The Congress itself.
It was prepared through.
Regional consultations.
Together with UNESCO in the Commonwealth of Learning, we invited experts in the field of open education and open educational resources in every region in every UNESCO region in the world.
In order to come together, it was gathering of at least 3040 fifty stakeholders per region to come together for two days and to identify the challenges and also then to make regional recommendations.
How to work on the mainstreaming international mainstreaming of IOR in the future.
So not only how to prepare national policies on our, But then to prepare recommendations how to go on how to, how to develop international cooperation.
So these were the six regional consultations prior to the Congress.
The Second World War we are Congress had these three objectives, so it was like the first one to bring together.
A worldwide community, on one hand, experts and stakeholders from the field, on the other hand, becausw UNESCO.
As you know, as you are aware and because it was an Intergovernmental Congress International Congress, we invited of course also governments or UNESCO.
Member States were invited to send their ministers of education or higher education and we together with UNESCO, we invited them to.
Come to Slovenia.
These were the identified 5 challenges which were which will be also some part of the discussions and the presentation from my UNESCO colleague who will speak right after me.
The Congress itself and I do not say it only as a Slovenian representative, but it was a huge success.
We gathered 500 people from all over the world, more than 100 countries were presented in Indiana, and among them we had 14 ministers of education and higher education.
That was quite much more around 10 ministers more than at the first world or your Congress, so that we had a huge political commitment from governments.
So it.
Was also ministers from all over the world.
Many came from Europe of course, but we had also ministers from Asia from Latin America and from the Arab world.
So for this we are.
We are very proud the Congress itself.
The program had some space for discussions and those discussions and working groups.
Divide it into the five challenges the topics were of course also to deliberate on the recommendations which were prepared by the by the regional consultations, so those those were on the table.
On the other hand, becausw, we and UNESCO we had the wish not to conclude the Congress only again with a another declaration in the field of Ovr.
The goal was to go to make a step further.
If we had the subtitle that this Congress.
Should carry the title from commitment to action, so our goal was in the end that would be adopted.
A action plan to put those recommendations identified already and then also discussed at the Congress itself.
To put it in the document to give really instructions or ideas for the way forward.
So one of the two outputs of the Congress was the so called you gonna ovr action plan.

And because we had many ministers present and we gathered them then together, because ministers like to talk also among each other in a more private way, we gathered them together in at a ministerial roundtable and.
And they already then they finally also agreed on a statement on or we are, which can be seen at still at the Congress website.

To you afterwards.

UNESCO organized its every two year major government governing.

List of recommendations.

We somehow.

We already pushed the Secretariat that they organized a online consultation about the document itself.
OK, it was only a short period of time last summer.
But however we had a big.
Big input by by Member States.

By by by the whole world and now even for the recommendation process, UNESCO is not obliged to to ask Member States or especially to ask stakeholders for their inputs on a standard setting instrument which they adopt in the end.
But we said, why not making this whole process really inclusive and opened up.
We asked them look when we will have the first draft of this recommendation.
Based on the outputs of the World Congress, then why not putting it online?
And this happened just until a few weeks ago.
This document, the 1st Zero Draft, was prepared and and.
, dated by a group of international experts, again from every region in the world, again led by our colleague from the Ovr chair and also colleagues here from Slovenia.

By people like you and we received, I suppose meter you will say more than 100.
Inputs and proposes to include into this draft.
This period ended in beginning of June, and this expert group that I said was responsible to really to accommodate all proposals or all draft texts, and this happened in the last weeks.

The chance to come back with their with their inputs and proposals, but on a for more formal way and after a period of a few months UNESCO will then again gather everything together and and come up with a new draft.

Those who wish to do so to take part in a certain so-called special committee.
They call it, and those Member States who will be then part of this special committee which will meet.

Not to vote, but to debate again and then to adopt the final recommendation so that this is the process.

Which I wanted to to show, but here it's important in my position is not to present to you because I think my colleague from UNESCO, who will be now with us online.

We are still in the leading position and we are really happy and somehow proud that we opened up such a.

Old organization as UNESCO, so you can imagine it's an old construction after the Second World War, which does not work in a very effective way sometimes, but we are happy that we succeeded to open this organization up.

Formal and.
Languages, but two working languages, so the texts are always available in English and French at this time, so this is from my point up to now.
What I wanted to present to you.
